question.text: Bond angle in <math><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> is closer to <math><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math> while that in <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> is <math><mn>104.5</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Which of the following best explains this structural feature?

options.text: Due to larger size of the lone pair electron cloud, there is larger lone pair – bond pair repulsion in <math><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> compared to <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> .

Higher electronegativity of nitrogen concentrates the bond pair electron cloud near the central atom which increases the bond pair – bond pair repulsion which in turn decreases the bond angle in <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> .

Energy difference between <math><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi></math> and <math><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi></math> orbitals is quite high and hence the lone pair on phosphorous prefers to occupy unhybridized <math><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo>-</mo></math> orbital rather than hybridized <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></math> hybridized orbital which causes its <math><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo>-</mo></math> orbital energy to increase.
Phosphorous forms <math><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">π</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">π</mi></math> bonds while nitrogen does not.

solution.text: In the hydrides of group <math><mn>15</mn></math> and group <math><mn>16</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi></math> (except <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> and <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> ) the energy difference between <math><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> and <math><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></math> orbital’s is quite high. Hybridization increases the energy of <math><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> orbital so much that lone pair rather prefers to occupy unhybridized s orbital. For example, in <math><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> , <math><mn>600</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> of energy is required to hybridize the central atom. So, to avoid such energy demanding hybridization P forms bonds with unhybridized p orbitals leaving the lone pair in the spherical s orbital which leads to a bond angle close to <math><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math> .
